docs.lead_paragraph: A woman who had an abortion after a test showed that her female fetus had a serious disease and would not survive infancy is suing Lenox Hill Hospital and a laboratory over the diagnosis, saying an autopsy found the fetus was male and perfectly normal. In a lawsuit filed earlier this month in Manhattan Federal Court, the woman, Janet Sheikhan, charges that the hospital and Genetrix, a laboratory in Yonkers, mishandled Mrs. Sheikhan's amniocentesis, a test routinely performed on pregnant women over 35 for genetic abnormalities, possibly switching hers with that of another pregnant woman.

headline.main: Woman Sues Over Lab Test That Prompted Abortion

docs.abstract: Janet Shiekhan, who had an abortion after test showed that her female fetus had serious a disease and would not survive infancy, is suing Lenox Hill Hospital and the laboratory, Genetrix; says an autopsy found that fetus was male and perfectly normal; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A woman who had an abortion after a test showed that her female fetus had a serious disease and would not survive infancy is suing Lenox Hill Hospital and a laboratory over the diagnosis, saying an autopsy found the fetus was male and perfectly...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many older Americans maintain an interest in sex, with nearly half of those over age 60 engaging in sexual activity at least once a month, according to a survey released today. The survey, commissioned and released by the National Council on the Aging, found that 39 percent of respondents said they were satisfied with the amount of sex they were having, while another 39 percent said they wished they had sex more frequently.

headline.main: Older People Enjoy Sex, Survey Says

docs.abstract: Survey by National Council on Aging finds that many older Americans maintain interest in sex, with nearly half of those over age 60 engaging in sexual activities at least once a month; finds that 39 percent of respondents say they are satisfied with amount of sex they are having, while another 39 percent say they wish they had sex more frequently (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As an obstetrician-gynecologist I am not surprised that some women request Caesarean deliveries for no medical reason (Science Times, Sept. 22). In these cases, patients commonly say they want to avoid the pain or the work of labor. I believe this phenomenon is partially related to the ''quick fix'' society we live in.
docs.abstract: Dr Anne Foster-Rosales letter on Sept 22 article on Caesarean deliveries; contends that elective surgery like Caesarean section puts patient at unnecessary risk
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    As an obstetrician-gynecologist I am not surprised that some women request Caesarean deliveries for no medical reason (Science Times, Sept. 22). In these cases, patients commonly say they want to avoid the pain or the work of labor....

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Sept. 22 Science Times article presents the controversy over Caesarean births but does little to highlight an important piece of the discussion: Who really controls the birthing process?
docs.abstract: Katie Kramer letter contends pregnant women who choose to deliver by Caesarean section should not be criticized but appreciated for their efforts to control their own birthing process
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Your Sept. 22 Science Times article presents the controversy over Caesarean births but does little to highlight an important piece of the discussion: Who really controls the birthing process?

docs.lead_paragraph: A state law that cuts off supplementary welfare benefits to recipients who have additional children would be repealed under a bipartisan bill introduced yesterday. About 25,000 children have been denied benefits since the family cap went into effect in 1993, said Jacqueline Tencza, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Human Services. Ms. Tencza said the policy encouraged welfare recipients to take responsibility for their families.

headline.main: Bill Would Reverse Welfare Family Cap

docs.abstract: New Jersey state law that cuts off supplementary welfare benefits to recipients who have additional children would be repealed under bipartisan bill introduced in state legislature (S)
docs.snippet: A state law that cuts off supplementary welfare benefits to recipients who have additional children would be repealed under a bipartisan bill introduced yesterday.    About 25,000 children have been denied benefits since the family cap went into...

docs.lead_paragraph: HOW do mother mice know how to look after their babies when there is no one to tell them what to do? By instinct, meaning that their maternal behavior is in some way programmed into their genes. Biologists have now identified one gene involved. By a curious twist the gene is one that is sculpted or imprinted by the father in a special way, giving male mice a role in shaping the female's maternal behavior.

headline.main: Good Maternal Behavior Is Linked to the Genes of a Father

docs.abstract: Biologists identify gene involved in maternal behavior displayed by mice; by a curious twist, gene is one that is sculpted or imprinted by father in a special way, giving male mice a role in shaping female's maternal behavior (M)
